please test this

@shikhar I think it's totally reasonably despite everything being bundled into a KIP to accept this incrementally. If you want to get the details of the fmwk stuff sorted and merged and then focus on getting all the xforms merged, I think that'd be reasonable. We've definitely got KIP-4 as an example where we incrementally merge large KIP changes in multiple PRs.

```
scala2.12/streams/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/kstream/KeyValueMapper.java:20:8: Unused import - org.apache.kafka.common.serialization.Serde.
```

Example output with two sub-topologies:

```
ProcessorTopology:
	KSTREAM-SOURCE-0000000000:
		topics:		[topic1]
		children:	[KSTREAM-MAP-0000000001]
	KSTREAM-MAP-0000000001:
		children:	[KSTREAM-FILTER-0000000004, KSTREAM-FILTER-0000000007]
	KSTREAM-FILTER-0000000004:
		children:	[KSTREAM-SINK-0000000003]
	KSTREAM-SINK-0000000003:
		topic:		X-Counts-repartition
	KSTREAM-FILTER-0000000007:
		children:	[KSTREAM-SINK-0000000006]
	KSTREAM-SINK-0000000006:
		topic:		X-KSTREAM-MAP-0000000001-repartition

ProcessorTopology:
	KSTREAM-SOURCE-0000000008:
		topics:		[X-KSTREAM-MAP-0000000001-repartition]
		children:	[KSTREAM-LEFTJOIN-0000000009]
	KSTREAM-LEFTJOIN-0000000009:
		states:		[Counts]
	KSTREAM-SOURCE-0000000005:
		topics:		[X-Counts-repartition]
		children:	[KSTREAM-AGGREGATE-0000000002]
	KSTREAM-AGGREGATE-0000000002:
		states:		[Counts]

```
@guozhangwang Updated

The point is, in either way how the `WindowedSer/Deser` was created (either explicitly internal of Streams, or via reflection from the config class name), the inner serde should always be set after it is constructed since otherwise it cannot be used.

I think it is better to have the config name sth. like `key[value].serializer[deserializer].inner.class`? 

And instead of creating a `ProducerConfig` object just to call its `getConfiguredInstance` I think we can just inline this function inside `configure`.
LGTM overall. Could you respond to @ijuma 's comment?
test this please.

> LGTM overall. Could you respond to @ijuma 's comment? Thanks, @guozhangwang ! I was unable to respond here, so I went to "FIles changed" tab of the pull request and replied there: Unfortunately that answer is not displayed here. @ijuma, is it visible to you in the diff?

@guozhangwang @enothereska  - this seems to fix the smoke test (at least it has passed everytime i've ran it locally).
Main problems:
1. Use of TestTimestampExtractor causes the logs to roll and segments to get deleted. Depending on timing this would result in some of the produced data never being consumed.
2. Use of UnlimitedWindows for window operations also causes the logs to roll and segments being deleted as the timestamp is always 0.
3. The way we determined when to end the test was more black arts than science! I've tried to make it more deterministic
I'm not overly concerned, however generally we shouldn't write code that is not used. So my preference is to remove them unless they are needed. Dead code is dead code. But, whatever...

Test failures look like they are legit. Same in each build:
org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.StreamThreadTest.shouldCloseActiveTasksThatAreAssignedToThisStreamThreadButAssignmentHasChangedBeforeCreatingNewTasks

@guozhangwang - that is fine with me. I agree with the tech-debt and i think we should really focus the next release on bug fixing, tech-debt, usability etc. 
If we get this in i'm more than happy to tackle your suggestions above

@amethystic, if you search for `EasyMock` in our tests, you'll find many examples. The idea is to mock the `FileChannel.read` method to verify that `readFully` works correctly for the various cases: end of stream is reached before buffer is full, buffer is filled with a single read, buffer is filled after multiple reads, etc.

The existing unit tests don't exercise these different paths (since they already passed before your change).

@benstopford, sorry for the delay. I hope to have a chance spend some time on this on Monday (if Ewen doesn't beat me to it).
Can we please close this PR now that we have established that the issue has been fixed? Thanks.
cc @junrao
Closed @ijuma

The integration/unit test we added reproduced the spurious metric value during deletion for 
`PreferredReplicaImbalanceCount`  and `OfflinePartitionsCount` but could not produce an unexpected value for `UnderReplicatedPartitions`

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/573/
Test FAILed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

Code checkstyle failed:

```
scala2.12/streams/src/test/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/kstream/internals/WindowedStreamPartitionerTest.java:31: Using the '.*' form of import should be avoided - java.util.*.
```

Actually we managed to get unexpected values for UnderReplicatedPartitions while creating and deleting topics. 

We can't fix it like the other 2 metrics because ReplicaManager, which emits this metric, does not have access to TopicDeletionManager (held in KafkaController). 

Currently in KafkaServer, ReplicaManager is created before KafkaController so we can't pass it in a reference to the TopicDeletionManager. We're actually unsure if changing the order will have side effects ...

Also we do not need to add these two configs into StreamsConfig, just as we did not add `key.serializer.encoding` used in StringSerializer in ProducerConfig. Instead, we should just mention them in the javadoc above as StringSerializer.
